explanation:
For determining whether any statements in OS_mount constitute dead code, the analyser needs the definitions and semantics that affect control flow, side-effects and observable outputs. Each listed symbol is required for the following reasons:

- OS_CHECK_STRING: This macro is invoked at the top of the function and may perform parameter validation and an early return. Its exact behaviour (conditions checked and whether it returns/sets return_code) directly affects reachability of the code that follows.
- OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG: The macro uses/returns this error value; to see if the macro can cause an early return or make later code unreachable, the concrete error constant is needed.

- OS_filesys_internal_record_t: The function reads fields from this structure (flags, device_name, virtual_mountpt, system_mountpt). The struct layout is needed to know field sizes (for sizeof usage in OS_CHECK_STRING) and to know which fields exist and their types — all used in decisions and side-effects.
- device_name, virtual_mountpt, system_mountpt, flags (fields): The code uses sizeof(filesys->device_name) and sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) in checks, checks system_mountpt[0], inspects and updates flags, and copies into virtual_mountpt. These determine whether checks can fail, whether the strncpy writes anything, and whether flag-updates are observable or redundant.

- OS_filesys_table and OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: The call filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token) must be understood: whether it can return NULL, perform side-effects, or map tokens to the same object every time. This affects whether subsequent accesses to filesys are valid and whether code using filesys might be dead if the mapping never yields a usable pointer.
- OS_ObjectIdGetByName: This call controls whether the inner block runs at all (it sets return_code and token). Its return semantics and side-effects determine reachability of most of the function body.
- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_object_token_t: These are part of the ObjectIdGetByName call signature; their semantics (e.g. whether certain inputs always fail) can change whether the function ever reaches branches, so they must be known.
- OS_SUCCESS: Numeric value used to test success; needed to interpret all return_code comparisons and to see whether later code is conditional or always executed.

- OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl: Called to perform the actual mount operation; its return values and side-effects (including whether it updates filesys->flags or other global state) determine whether subsequent flag updates and strncpy are necessary or redundant. If the impl always fails or always succeeds in a way that makes later writes redundant, that affects whether those writes are dead.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease and OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish: The function always calls OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token) after using token; if release has observable side-effects (e.g. commits changes, triggers notifications) then the call is not dead. Knowing whether release is required or a no-op is necessary to judge deadness.

- OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_FIXED, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_READY, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL: The flags bit masks are used to decide branch selection and to mark the filesystem mounted. To decide if the flag write is dead, the analyser must know what bits mean, whether they overlap, and whether those flags are used elsewhere (i.e. whether setting them changes observable behaviour).
- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND: These error codes are written into return_code in multiple places. In particular, the final if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS) { return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND; } may overwrite earlier, more specific errors. Knowing the intended semantics (numeric values and whether override is deliberate) helps determine if earlier error assignments are effectively dead (i.e. always replaced) or meaningful.

- strncpy (or equivalent stdlib semantics): The function copies mountpoint into filesys->virtual_mountpt; to decide if this copy is dead one must know whether virtual_mountpt is later read/used and whether the copy can be elided without changing program behaviour. Understanding strncpy semantics (bounds/truncation and possible no-op cases) is necessary.

In short, these symbols determine control-flow decisions, observable side-effects, and error-reporting behaviour. Without them it is impossible to conclude whether any assignment, call, or branch in OS_mount could be removed without affecting program behaviour (i.e. whether it is dead code).
